This specifically indicates the chapter, and below it lists the names separately.

One, anger, two, resentment, three, vexation, four, concealment, five, deception, six, flattery, seven, arrogance, eight, harm, nine, jealousy, ten, stinginess, eleven, shamelessness, twelve, lack of conscience, thirteen, lack of faith, fourteen, laziness, fifteen, negligence, sixteen, dullness, seventeen, agitation, eighteen, forgetfulness, nineteen, incorrect knowledge, twenty, distraction.
As for anger, it is the nature of being resentful towards a present unfavorable object, and its function is to obstruct non-anger and hold grudges.
Holding a weapon means a weapon.
Those who harbor anger and resentment often give rise to violent evil bodily actions, so they are included in one part of hatred.
Hatred means, due to anger as the forerunner, harboring evil and not letting go, with the nature of binding grudges, it can obstruct non-hatred and has the function of causing distress.
Those who are distressed and those who harbor grudges are unable to endure and are always distressed.
Vexation means, due to anger and resentment as the forerunner, pursuing and touching violent evil, with the nature of being resentful, it can obstruct non-vexation and has the function of stinging.

The meaning of pursuing and touching, etc. refers to pursuing past evils, touching present adverse conditions, the mind then becomes resentful, often giving rise to violent and vulgar words, and stinging others. It is also a part of hatred.
Concealment means, regarding one's own faults, fearing loss of benefits and praise, hiding them as the nature, it can obstruct non-concealment and has the function of causing remorse and distress.

As for remorse and vexation, when one conceals a transgression, one will later necessarily feel remorse and vexation and will not be at ease. If one does not fear future suffering, it is a part of craving and delusion.
As for concealing a transgression, it is categorized as a part of delusion.
If one conceals a transgression for fear of losing profit and fame, it is categorized as a part of craving.

As for deceit, in order to protect profit and fame, one falsely displays one's virtues and deceives. Its nature is that of being crooked, and it obstructs non-deceit and makes a living through evil means.
As for falsely displaying, etc., it means that the deceitful one harbors ulterior motives in the mind and often displays unreal evil means for making a living. This is a part of craving and delusion.

As for flattery, in order to deceive others, one falsely sets up a different manner. Its nature is that of being crooked and obsequious, and it obstructs non-flattery and admonishment. Its activity is that of making a living through evil means.

As for deceiving others, etc., it means that the crooked and obsequious one, in order to deceive others, obsequiously conforms to the times and falsely sets up expedient means in order to grasp the intentions of others;
or in order to conceal one's own faults and not submit to the correct admonishments of teachers and friends. It is also a part of craving and delusion.
Arrogance is by nature a deep attachment to oneâ€™s own prosperity and a drunken haughtiness, and its activity is that of obstructing nonarrogance and acting as the support of defilement.
As for the meaning of support of defilement, when one is drunk with arrogance, all defiled dharmas are born and grow. It is a part of craving.
Nonarrogance is the absence of craving.
Harmfulness is by nature a lack of pity for sentient beings and the injuring of them. Its activity is that of obstructing nonharmfulness and oppressing.
As for the meaning of oppressing, one who is harmful oppresses others. It is categorized as a part of hatred.
If we discuss the difference between harmfulness and hatred, harmfulness obstructs nonharmfulness and directly obstructs compassion;
hatred obstructs nonhatred and directly obstructs kindness.
Also, hatred is able to take life, while harmfulness only injures others. This is the difference.
ENVY is by nature a jealousy and an inability to bear the good qualities and prosperity of others, and its activity is that of obstructing nonenvy and causing mental distress.
As for the meaning of worry and sorrow, the jealous person, hearing or seeing others' toil, deeply worries and sorrows, and is not at ease, and therefore it is also a part of anger.

As for the meaning of stinginess, one is attached to the Dharma and wealth, and is unable to give generously, and stinginess is its nature. It is able to obstruct non-stinginess and cause miserliness, and it is also a part of greed.ğŸ”½Shamelessness means not regarding oneself or the Dharma, and despising the virtuous and good is its nature. It is able to obstruct shame and cause the growth of evil behavior as its activity.

As for the meaning of not regarding, it means not regarding anything about oneself or the Dharma, despising the virtuous and good, and not feeling ashamed of faults and evil, it is able to obstruct shame and cause the growth of evil behavior.ğŸ”½Lack of conscience means not regarding the world, and revering and respecting evil is its nature. It is able to obstruct conscience and cause the growth of evil behavior as its activity.

As for the meaning of not regarding the world, etc., it means not regarding anything in the world, revering and respecting evil, and not feeling ashamed of faults and offenses, it is able to obstruct conscience and cause the growth of evil behavior.

As for disbelief, it is the nature of the mind being defiled by not enduring, delighting in, or desiring real virtues and abilities, and its activity is to obstruct pure mind and cause one to fall into dependence.
As for falling into dependence, those who lack faith are often lazy.
As for laziness, it is the nature of being indolent in cultivating good and cutting off evil, and its activity is to obstruct vigor and increase defilements.
As for increasing defilements, it is because the lazy one nourishes and increases defilements.

As for heedlessness, it is the nature of being unrestrained in not being able to guard and cultivate defiled and pure dharmas, and its activity is to obstruct heedfulness and serve as the support for increasing evil and harming good.
What is the essence of this heedlessness?
It is said:
The three roots of laziness, being unable to guard and cultivate defiled and pure dharmas, are collectively called heedlessness. Apart from these four dharmas, it has no separate essence.
It is also said:
Pride, doubt, and so forth also have this ability. Why are they not relied upon to establish it?

It is said:ğŸ”½The essence of heedlessness is the nature of being unrestrained in not being able to guard and cultivate defiled and pure dharmas. It is established based on the four dharmas of laziness, lack of shame, lack of embarrassment, and lack of vigilance. It is not established based on other dharmas.
Pride and so forth are in the four directions, their power and function are weak, therefore they are not established based on them.
Among these four dharmas, which one is superior to the others, such as pride?
It is said:
They obstruct the three roots of goodness, they obstruct universal exertion, the others do not have this ability, therefore they are not superior.
As for torpor, it makes the mind incapable with regard to objects as its nature, it is able to obstruct serenity and vipaÅ›yanÄ as its activity.
Some say:
How is torpor different from delusion?
It is said:
Delusion has the nature of confusion and obscurity with regard to objects, it directly obstructs non-delusion, but not sluggishness;
Torpor has the characteristic of sluggishness with regard to objects, it directly obstructs serenity but not confusion, therefore the two are not the same.
As for restlessness, it makes the mind not tranquil with regard to objects as its nature, it is able to obstruct equanimity and Å›amatha as its activity.
Forgetfulness is by nature the inability to remember clearly the various objects one has experienced, and its activity is that of obstructing correct memory and acting as the support of distraction.
It is said to be the support of distraction because when one is forgetful, the mind is distracted.
There is an opinion that forgetfulness is categorized as a part of memory, because it is memory associated with the passions.

There is an opinion that it is categorized as a part of delusion, because the YogÄcÄrabhÅ«mi ÅšÄstra says that it is a part of delusion. Delusion causes the loss of memory and is therefore called forgetfulness.
There is an opinion that it is categorized as a part of both memory and delusion, because the previous two sources indicate this by implication.
Incorrect knowing is by nature the erroneous understanding of the contemplated object, and its activity is that of obstructing correct knowing and acting as the support of transgression.
It is the support of transgression, because one who is lacking in correct knowing commits many transgressions.

This dharma is said to be categorized as a part of discernment, because it is discernment associated with the passions.ğŸ”½There is an opinion that it is categorized as a part of delusion, because the YogÄcÄrabhÅ«mi ÅšÄstra says that it is a part of delusion. Delusion causes incorrect knowing and is therefore called incorrect knowing.
It is categorized as a part of delusion, because the YogÄcÄrabhÅ«mi ÅšÄstra says that it is a part of delusion.
It is called wrong knowledge because it causes knowledge to be incorrect.
Some say that
it is categorized as a part of both delusion and knowledge, because the above two passages speak of it as being a part of both.
DISTRACTEDNESS is by nature that which causes the mind to flow out and scatter, and its activity is that of obstructing right samÄdhi and acting as a support for evil discernment.
It is said to be the support for evil discernment because one who is distracted generates evil discernment.
Some ask,
What is the difference between distractedness and agitation?
We reply,
Distractedness causes the mind to easily take objects, while agitation causes the mind to be uncalm. This is the difference in their natures.
The above statement that they are modes of activity and species of the passions means that their substance is the same as the passions.

The ten such as anger, resentment, etc., and loss of mindfulness, incorrect knowledge, and negligence, these thirteen dharmas are the differentiated states within the fundamental ones. If there is no shamelessness, no conscience, agitation, torpor, distraction, lack of faith, and laziness, these seven dharmas are the nature of the same outflow as the fundamental ones.
Some say:
Since these seven have separate substances, why are they called the same outflow?
They say:
Because they arise only when the fundamental ones are the cause, they are called the same outflow.
Sixth, the four undetermined ones:
This is a separate heading, with the names listed below:
First, sleep, second, remorse, third, investigation, fourth, reflection.

Sleep causes the body to be unfree, with obscurity and brevity as its nature, and obstructs insight as its activity - that is, vipaÅ›yanÄ. It is said that in the state of sleep, the body is unfree, the mind is extremely dark and inferior, and does not function.

The character â€œvagueâ€ distinguishes it from samÄdhi, and â€œbriefâ€ distinguishes it from the state of being awake. It is in order to show that sleep is not without substance and function that it is given a separate name, just as the other hindrances and bonds are associated with mind.

As for â€œregret,â€ the action of regretting what one has done badly is its nature, and its activity is that of obstructing concentration. It is a case of the name of the result being given to the cause, because one regrets what one has done badly only after it is done.
Regretting what one has not done is also included in regret.
For example, one may regret and say,
â€œI did not do such and such a thing, and that is my regret.â€

There is an interpretation that these two have as their substance the four aggregates associated with the feeling of distress. There is another interpretation that they have as their substance the four aggregates, because they are associated with mental consciousness. There is an interpretation that they each have a separate substance, because their modes of activity differ from other mental activities. They are said to exist conventionally, in accordance with the characteristics of delusion.ğŸ”½As for â€œapplied thoughtâ€ and â€œsustained thought,â€ applied thought is the mental activity of seeking, which causes the mind to be distracted and to evolve coarsely with regard to a verbal image.
Sustained thought is the mental activity of investigating, which causes the mind to be distracted and to evolve subtly with regard to a verbal image.
Second, the function of the two dharmas, both taking the state of body and mind being at ease or not at ease as their function.
That is to say, the objects of mental discourse are the objects grasped by the mind, which mostly rely on names and expressions, called the objects of mental discourse.
Some say:
Are the two dharmas of investigation and analysis real or false?
They say:
Both take a part of thought and discernment as their essence. If they make the mind at ease, it is the part of thought;
if they make the mind not at ease, it is the part of discernment.
It is because thought is slow and subtle;
discernment is quick and coarse.
Therefore, we know that if it makes the mind at ease, it uses thought without discernment; if it makes the mind not at ease, it uses discernment without thought.

If we follow the explanation of the Great Master Tongzhao, there is both primary and secondary. If it primarily uses thought, then the quick discernment follows the thought and can make the mind at ease; if it primarily uses discernment, then the slow thought follows the discernment and also makes it not at ease.
This is their joint use.
Third, there are roughly eleven kinds of form dharmas:
As for form, there is form with resistance and form with color. The five faculties that support it are only five, and the six objects that it perceives are six, which are the reflections of the two.
This specifically indicates the chapters, and below it lists the names separately.
One, eye; two, ear; three, nose; four, tongue; five, body; six, form; seven, sound; eight, smell; nine, taste; ten, touch; eleven, form included in the dharma realm.
As for the one eye, it means the function of illuminating and seeing. The Sanskrit word caká¹£u means exhaustion of activity.
Because the eye can exhaustively engage with all forms, it is called exhaustion of activity.
As for translating it as eye, the substance and function correspond, and it is based on the Tang language.
As for the two ears, they mean the function of hearing. The Sanskrit word Å›rotra means able to hear sounds.
Repeatedly hearing these sounds, up to the point where one is able to hear them.
Ear is translated as such because the substance and function correspond, following the Tang language.
The third is the nose, which has the meaning of being able to smell. The Sanskrit word ghrÄá¹‡a means able to smell.
Because it smells fragrances and foul odors, it is able to smell fragrances and foul odors repeatedly through this.
Nose is translated as such because it combines substance and function, following the Tang language.
The fourth is the tongue, which has the meaning of being able to taste. The Sanskrit word jihvÄ means able to taste.
The YogÄcÄrabhÅ«mi ÅšÄstra states:
It can relieve hunger and thirst, frequently engage in discussions, and express itself through speech. This is called the tongue.
It encompasses both the ultimate and conventional meanings.
Tongue is translated as such because it also combines substance and function, following the Tang language.

As for the five aggregates, the two meanings of accumulation and support are called aggregates, referring to the accumulation of the great elements and the support of the faculties. The Sanskrit word kÄya means accumulation, and the body faculty is the support for many dharmas, as the faculties follow it and are accumulated everywhere, thus it is called the body.
As for the translation of body, the meaning of substance corresponds to the Tang language.

The substance is precisely the faculties. As for the five being called faculties, they all have the meaning of origination and predominance, thus they take the eight dharmas of the primary and secondary elements as their substance, which are the faculties that are the support for consciousness.
As for the six forms, they are taken by the eyes and are of twenty-five kinds.

Namely, the four realities of blue, yellow, red, and white, the eight appearances of long, short, square, round, coarse, fine, high, and low, the eight states of correct, incorrect, light, shadow, bright, dark, smoke, dust, clouds, and mist, the two distant colors of distant color and table color, and the one empty color of empty color. These are all the meaning of manifesting in space and place, and the color of complexion.
Because it corresponds to the eye consciousness, it is called form, which is the general name of form.
As for the seven sounds, they are created by the four great elements and are the meaning grasped by the ear faculty.
In total, there are five causes that encompass the twelve kinds of sounds.
The five causes are:
First, the characteristic, which is the meaning grasped by the ear faculty. This one is the general, and the other four are the specific.
Second, the benefit and harm, which establish the first three kinds of sounds, saying:
The pleasant sound is beneficial, the unpleasant sound is harmful, and the sound that is contrary to both is common to both.
Third, the distinction of causes includes the next three types:

Sounds caused by the great elements that are appropriated, such as speech; sounds caused by the great elements that are not appropriated, such as the sounds of trees; and sounds caused by both kinds of great elements, such as the sounds of hands and drums.
Fourth, the distinction of statements includes three: sounds that are commonly accepted in the world, which are included in worldly language;
sounds that are produced by accomplishment, which are spoken by the sages;
and sounds that are conceptually constructed, which are spoken by non-Buddhists.

Fifth, the distinction of words includes three: sounds that are included in the valid cognition of the words of the sages, which are the eight kinds of words of the sages. Sage means correct. These eight kinds of words do not go beyond seeing, hearing, knowing, and perceiving, and they encompass the six sense faculties, because the nose, tongue, and body all perceive. In responding to people as appropriate, if one sees, one says one sees; up to the fourth, if one knows, one says one knows. If one does not see, one says one does not see; up to the eighth, if one does not know, one says one does not know. This is the word of the sages.
If the first view says what is not seen is seen, and what is seen is not seen, up to the eighth saying what is not known is known, this is also eight kinds of non-holy speech.
The Huayan Commentary only has eleven kinds, adding echo according to the VijÃ±aptimÄtratÄ, making twelve. More research is needed.
As for the eight fragrances, they are what is taken by the nose because they have the meaning of being able to be smelled.
There are six kinds in total, namely:
good fragrance, bad fragrance, equal fragrance, innate fragrance, compounded fragrance, and transformed fragrance.
The nine tastes are what is taken by the tongue because they have the meaning of being able to be tasted.
There are twelve kinds, namely:
bitter, sour, sweet, spicy, salty, bland, agreeable, disagreeable, both contradictory and non-contradictory, innate, compounded, and transformed.
As for the ten contacts, they are what is taken by the body because they have the meaning of being able to be touched, therefore called contact.
There are twenty-six kinds, namely:

Earth, water, fire, wind, lightness, heaviness, roughness, smoothness, slowness, quickness, coldness, warmth, hardness, softness, hunger, thirst, fullness, strength, weakness, dullness, itching, stickiness, aging, sickness, death, and emaciation.
The first four are real, the rest are all established based on the four great elements.
Someone said:
If the rest are false, what is the condition for the body consciousness?
He said:
It is because it is conditioned by the real. Since it is conditioned by the real, how can one know that the five consciousnesses and the mental consciousness distinguish lightness, etc.?
As for the form included in the dharma realm, it refers to the past dharmas without substance, which can be the object of cognition.
This is of five kinds, namely:
Extremely distant form, which is named extremely distant form because it is analyzed by the contemplation of conceptualization and reaches the ultimate atom in the form that obstructs it.
It is also said:

Looking up at the blue, yellow, and other colors in the sky is the manifest color. If one looks down at it, this manifest color is so far away that it is difficult to see, so it is called the color of extreme remoteness.
As for the color of extreme subtlety, it is also a conceptual observation that analyzes the color of Mount Sumeru and other obstructive colors down to the most subtle particles.
It is also said:
On the basis of color, one analyzes length, shortness, shape, coarseness, and fineness, down to the most subtle particles.
As for the obstructive, it refers to the color of the sense faculties and so forth. The light and dark colors are what is obstructed.

The color of the result of concentration refers to the concentration of liberation, as well as the bodies of fish, rice, meat, and mountains, and is also called the color produced by the mastery of concentration.

Concentration refers to meditative concentration. The color produced by mastery refers to the light that appears when a bodhisattva enters concentration, as well as the various forms and realms that are seen, such as when one enters the concentration of fiery light, then the fiery light appears and so forth.
The form that is attracted by feeling refers to the form of non-revealing form established by the seeds of superior volition of the precepts and non-precepts.

Moreover, feeling is the experience, and attraction is the attraction. It is like receiving the various precepts. The precepts are dharmas of form. The precepts that are received are the form that is attracted by feeling.
The form that is imagined refers to the sense faculties and sense objects that are transformed by the sixth consciousness's false imagination. They lack real function, so this name is established.
Some say that the other four forms of form have names that can be discussed, but how can that which is attracted by feeling also be called form?
It is said that the name is established based on the form of good and evil that arises from what is to be guarded.
All four of these are partially real and partially conceptual.
Fourth, there are twenty-four kinds of dharmas that are neither form nor mind.
These are the states of form and mind. The names such as attainment are established based on a part and a state of the previous three dharmas.
Because dharmas are of two kinds, this distinguishes what is not mind, and thus establishes its name.
This is a general statement of the chapter, below it lists them separately:

1. Attainment, 2. Life faculty, 3. Homogeneous character of beings, 4. Nature of ordinary beings, 5. Non-perception concentration, 6. Cessation concentration, 7. Non-perception retribution, 8. Name body, 9. Sentence body, 10. Syllable body, 11. Birth, 12. Abiding, 13. Aging, 14. Impermanence, 15. Continual flux, 16. Specific difference, 17. Association, 18. Speed, 19. Sequence, 20. Time, 21. Space, 22. Number, 23. Unitary nature, 24. Non-unitariness.
Obtainment means to encompass and accomplish, the meaning of not losing. It is the characteristic of not losing that form and mind arise and have not yet been destroyed.
The faculty of life is merely provisionally established based on the function of continuously maintaining form and mind, which is attracted by karma, on the seeds of the eighth consciousness.
Homogeneous character means similarity in kind. There is a distinction between humans and dharmas.

The homogeneous character of humans is like the homogeneous character of gods and the homogeneous character of humans. The homogeneous character of dharmas is like the homogeneous character of mind and the homogeneous character of form, etc.
The three vehicles and five natures provisionally establish this name based on humans, dharmas, and kinds.
The nature of ordinary beings is a certain function of the seeds of the two hindrances that causes the different kinds of destinies to be dissimilar, which is called the nature of ordinary beings.
The attainment of non-perception means that perception, etc. do not function, causing the body to be peaceful and harmonious, and is also called concentration.
Or it is said:

This concentration is a group of mind and thought that does not operate at all, yet it is called 'without thought.' Thought ceasing is foremost. It means that this non-Buddhist practitioner is disgusted with thought as if it were a disease, and eagerly seeks to be without thought, considering it to be subtle, and thus this concentration is named.

The concentration of cessation is that which causes the non-continuously operating mind and mental factors to cease. The continuously operating group of minds and mental factors of the sixth consciousness and the defiled seventh consciousness all cease completely, and this is the characteristic of this concentration.
In cultivating the concentration of non-thought, one has the thought of escape and cessation, and in the concentration of cessation, one has the thought of rest.
Moreover, non-thought is only for ordinary beings, and cessation is only for sages, and this is the difference between the two concentrations.
In general, on the basis of the seeds of the disgusted mind, the ability to obstruct the arising of the evolving consciousnesses is established as these two concentrations.

As for the retribution of non-thought, because one cultivates that concentration in the desire realm, one is reborn in that heaven realm as a result, and it is called the retribution of non-thought. It is a secondary formation of the name of non-thought.
As for the collection of names, it refers to single names that express intrinsic nature;
Two or more names are called a name aggregate;
Three or more names are called many name aggregates.
This refers to the aggregate of individual names.
A sentence is a single sentence, two sentences are called a sentence aggregate, and three or more sentences are called many sentence aggregates.
A single sentence expresses distinctions, and many sentences express the aggregate of individual sentences.
A syllable is a single syllable, which is able to serve as the basis for both names and sentences.
Like the single word to cut or the single word grass, it has no expressive power and is called a syllable.
The treatise does not speak of names and many names, taking the middle to encompass the broad and concise.
It also says:
Syllables that express meaning are like the characters in scriptures;
Those that do not express meaning are simply syllables, such as the alphabet and rhymes.
Arising means that which did not exist before now exists.
Abiding means temporarily remaining in an existent state.
Aging is the separation of the previous and later stages, also called decline and change. It is also said that dharmas are not static.
As for impermanence, it means existing now but not existing later, a different name for death.

Moreover, many holy teachings combine arising and ceasing to be impermanence. Arising is called existence, but existence is not always existent, unlike unconditioned dharmas. Cessation is called non-existence.
Non-existence is not always non-existent, unlike the horns of a rabbit. It is not the same as the permanence of unconditioned dharmas or the horns of a rabbit, so it is called impermanence.
Now, I only speak of death.
Transmigration means the uninterrupted continuity of cause and effect, from the past to the future.
Determinate difference means the mutual differences between good and evil causes and effects.
Harmony means causes and effects arising in combination with activities.
Some say:
Why is this general name of non-associated compositional factors now called associated?
The name non-associated simply excludes the previously associated mental factors.
This corresponding means the union of the above three dharmas' activities. How can they be confused?
Speed refers to the swift movement and flight of conditioned dharmas.
Sequence refers to the orderly arrangement of things, preventing disorder. Superior and inferior, above and below, left and right, front and back, all that has rules and regulations is included here.

Time refers to past, present, and future; formation, abiding, decay, and emptiness; the four seasons and three periods; years, months, days, and nights; the six periods and twelve divisions, established according to the directions. Therefore, it is called time.

Space refers to the boundaries of the realm of form, the basis of people and dharmas, or the ten directions, above and below, the six directions and four extremes, also established according to the directions.
Number refers to the names used to measure dharmas, or one, ten, one hundred, one thousand, up to incalculable.
As for the nature of combination, it means that the dharmas do not contradict each other.
As for the nature of non-combination, it means that because the characteristics of dharmas are contradictory,
the former is like a cause that accords with characteristics, while this is like a cause that contradicts characteristics.
Some say:
As for these twenty-four, in the previous three states, which dharma corresponds to which state?
To broadly speak, the one dharma of life-force is only a state of mind, because the function of maintaining continuity is on the seeds of the eighth consciousness.
The one nature of ordinary beings is only a state of what is distinguished, because it causes a separate function on the seeds of the two obstacles.

The two mindless samÄdhis, the karmic maturation of non-perception, are only nominally established on the basis of the king and what is distinguished. When the king and what is distinguished cease, it is called non-perception, etc.

The remaining nineteen kinds are common to form, mind, and mental factors, and are nominally established on the basis of the three. Like the similarity of groups, there is the similarity of form groups, the similarity of mind groups, and the similarity of mental factors groups.
Moreover, like speed, it is the form, mind, and mental factors that pass away and do not stop.
It is also like the definite difference between form and mind, form not being mind and mind not being form, and the definite non-reciprocal attraction between good causes and evil effects, and so on.
The rest can be explained by analogy.
Fifth, as for the unconditioned dharmas, there are briefly six kinds:
This is the chapter heading, with the specific enumeration below.

The first is the unconditioned of space, the second is the unconditioned of cessation through discernment, the third is the unconditioned of cessation not through discernment, the fourth is the unconditioned of immovable cessation, the fifth is the unconditioned of cessation of ideation and sensation, and the sixth is the unconditioned of suchness.
As for the unconditioned, it is the true nature of the preceding four states, thus it is said to be the true nature of consciousness.

Because the six classes of mental factors are the associated phenomena of consciousness, the eleven kinds of form dharmas are the objects of consciousness, and the dissociated formative forces are the states of consciousness, consciousness is their substance, and for this reason it is generally said to be the true nature of consciousness, with six kinds.
As for calling them unconditioned, wei means to make.
The previous ninety-four kinds are dharmas of arising and ceasing, all with creation, thus belonging to the conditioned.
Now these six dharmas are tranquil, profound, and eternally abiding, with nothing created, thus called unconditioned.
As for unconditioned space, it means in true reality being free from all obstructions, just like space, expansive and free from obstruction, taking its name from the analogy.
The meanings of the next five unconditioned dharmas are modeled on this explanation.
Cessation through discernment refers to discernment and cessation. Due to the wisdom of the absence of defilements, the true reality revealed by severing all defiled obstructions is given this name.
Cessation not through discernment means the originally pure nature of the one true Dharma realm is not revealed through the power of discernment severing and ceasing;
Or, the true reality revealed by conditioned dharmas not arising due to the absence of conditions.
For the above two meanings, this name is established.

Immovable refers to the truth manifested by the fourth dhyÄna, which is free from the first three dhyÄnas, beyond the three calamities and eight sufferings, and without the agitation of joy, bliss, etc. that moves the body and mind. This is named after what manifests it, hence it is called immovable.

Cessation of conceptualization and sensation refers to the truth manifested by the non-functioning of conceptualization and sensation in the sphere of nothingness. The name is established in this way.

Suchness means the principle is not false or inverted, hence it is called suchness. Such distinguishes it from the false, and ness distinguishes it from the inverted. The imagined and dependent natures should be understood in sequence.
It is also said:
Suchness reveals the meaning of true and permanent. Such is precisely ness. Ness is precisely the unconditioned.
From all dharmas above to here, it clarifies the one hundred dharmas, thus answering the initial question of what are all dharmas?

The pudgala is precisely non-self.
The absence of self is precisely the emptiness of self.

Ordinary beings all grasp at real dharmas outside of the mind, and also grasp at these dharmas as having real control. This is said to be non-existent. The non-existence is precisely their emptiness, without any separate substance.
Second, the non-self of dharmas.

As for the term dharma, it means that which guides and upholds. It refers to the essence of all dharmas, which although they uphold and guide the arising of understanding in beings, they also lack any superior nature or real sovereign power.
